titleStmt.title: An entry from the Journals of Hensley Henson

sourceDesc.bibl: Edited from the manuscripts in the custody of Durham Cathedral Library.

body.p: A beautiful day, sunny and quite mild. I finished the charge, and frittered away the rest of the day very uselessly. Also, I essayed to order my study–table, which had again become chaotic to the point of practical paralysis.

p.hi: I read through a little book by
The Hope of the World to come'
, in which he makes something like a protest against the anti–eschatological teaching of the Dean of S. Paul's.

body.p: The 8th volume of the Cambridge Ancient History arrived, a monstrous volume of more than 700 pages. It deals with 'Rome and the Mediterranean. 218–133 B.C.'. I buy these books, but I have no time to read them: and the pace of their publication is ever quickening. Before one book is finished with, it has become obsolete, and another must be read. I wonder whether it would not be a wiser course to leave all these modern books altogether alone, & limit one's reading to the great standards and the texts. The question of providing book–space for the waxing flood of new publications is becoming serious. And I draw near to the Three–score years & ten!
